ygData.subject: Re: An improvement over object evolution with CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, Well I did have second thoughts, because I was uncertain. I need to explore the possibilities of the method more before I have any hard conclusions.

From: "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
Subject: Re: An improvement over object evolution with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=tjEZIdumbY_Ti0Vw7QtBmjai8MWqr0ZgsXarYUSHSJ-lU6cdvGi_SOCOAg
X-Yahoo-Profile: petar_chervenski

Hi Ken,

Well I did have second thoughts, because I was uncertain. I need t=
o 
explore the possibilities of the method more before I have any hard 
con=
clusions. But here I will try to address most issues about it. 

I am conce=
rned with the fact that my particular method may not 
encompass all possibl=
e patterns, but only a small subset. There are 
many limits having a role i=
n this model, and if I remove these limits, 
this easily leads to huge arra=
ys of cells coming out from very simple 
CPPNs, or a sudden loss in phenoty=
pic variety. But generally the 
possibilities for the density patterns are =
unlimited. The only limits 
are the constraints of the internal physics wor=
ld they grow up in as 
well as the limits of the individual cell's "program=
s". 

I am not sure if there is really non-growth method for evolution of 
=
substrates, because of the reasons I highlight below.

I want to talk again=
 about the general issue. I am sorry if I repeat 
this too much. In fact, I=
 want to try to summarize the whole thing, 
the problem that is common to o=
bject development and substrate 
development with CPPNs. I believe that the=
 problem is near to be 
solved but it should be clear what exactly is the p=
roblem. 

There is a difference between size and complexity. Complexity is =

described in an infinite precision. The CPPN does it. But in reality, 
in =
a physics world (where objects are to be evolved), or a loose 
geometric re=
presentation of the physics world (where neural substrates 
are to be evolv=
ed), body size and density information is needed. 

Some people may ask why=
. First, having huge density early in evolution 
is unnecessary and expensi=
ve, because the complexity is low anyway. 
Second, by having the substrate =
*configuration* evolve by itself, the 
encoding can exploit the physics wor=
ld indirectly via the development 
and perhaps discover very minimal soluti=
ons early and later elaborate 
on them. 

For example, consider the HyperNE=
AT food gathering task. It is evident 
that the circular substrate takes mo=
re structure to evolve and be 
exploited effectively. But if HyperNEAT can =
arrange the substrate by 
itself, it should be able to discover both the ef=
fective configuration 
and the wiring very early in evolution, which would =
speed it up. But 
this is only my thought, it may not be true, we should re=
ally see it 
is proven experimentally. 

So, back to size/complexity. We ca=
n actually use any body size and 
density to approximate that complexity in=
 one final body at certain 
level of detail. No matter what the density is =
or how many cells there 
are, complexity is constant. So far only humans de=
cide body size and 
density. 

There are several questions coming out of al=
l this: 1) Can CPPNs 
potentially encode body size and density information =
just like they do 
encode body complexity, 2) If they do, to what extent, i=
.e. is it 
limited to a small subset of densities or potentially infinite (=
which 
is the solution that I am looking for). 

See, they are excellent at=
 generating patterns in space. But in a 
realistic physics world, the high-=
level patterns have to be 
interpreted in the appropriate way. The raw CPPN=
 output has just 
everything needed, but the pattern itself cannot *effecti=
vely* 
describe quantity/density of matter. And more, because substrates an=
d 
physics bodies are structures with finite size, all these patterns 
have=
 to be interpreted in a special way, completely different than a 
simple ma=
pping from a higher-dimensional space. This is because an 
isomorphic mappi=
ng like in HyperNEAT does not contain information 
about quantity of struct=
ural components, i.e. if I query for 100 links 
in 4D or 6D they are still =
100 links mapped back to 2D for example. 
And I am basically allowed to que=
ry for links/points anywhere in  
space, which I can't do in physics. 

The=
 ideal solution is such that *all* possible patterns from a CPPN 
collapse =
to isomorphic finite-sized bodies in the physics world. No 
exceptions - in=
troducing exceptions is the wrong way to solve the 
problem. Plus, the over=
all shape of the body and its internal 
structure (i.e. complexity) should =
be the same regardless of density 
and body size. 

I know that it is actua=
lly trivial to have another output that 
specifies matter density. But the =
range of possible densities vs. 
meaningful evolution dynamics is a bit uns=
atisfying. I remember one 
previous discussion we had about substrate evolu=
tion and I agree that 
a slight mutation should not make it jump from, say =
10000 nodes -> 100 trillion. So there should be some kind of scaling for th=
e range of 
densities that are acceptable in the domain. Plus, this does no=
t meet 
the requirement that the produced body should be finite in size for=
 
all possible patterns of the CPPN.

It looks like we should ask nature fo=
r an advice again. Here is one 
observation. From the biggest animals to th=
e smallest (actually most 
multicellular forms of life but not all), whales=
, elephants, humans, 
mice and insects, all start development from one smal=
l cell. OK the 
cells can vary in size among species but they all start fro=
m one very 
small cell. But the phenotypes vary in size and complexity, it =
is 
obvious. It looks like that DNA can encode huge complexity and body 
ma=
ss as well as little complexity and mass, and all of it unfolds from 
the s=
imple egg-cell. And DNA instructs that egg on how to unfold. 

Here is one =
logical idea based on that observation. If we assume that 
the quantity/den=
sity of matter and overall body size can be somehow 
represented as a patte=
rn in space, then, in order to have this variety 
of phenotypes, like with =
only 1 or many many structural components 
(call them cells), that entire p=
attern has to be "folded" into one 
spot and then left to unfold as specifi=
ed in the pattern itself, its 
internal "program" of how to unfold. 

But I=
 am afraid that my approach with the egg does not solve the 
problem when a=
 slight mutation can bump up the substrate density too 
much. Hope is not l=
ost, though - it is the general idea that we can 
make a pattern in space f=
olded in such a way that it describes 
instructions for development. If don=
e the right way, a slight change 
in the pattern should not lead to a huge =
change of matter quantity. It 
actually depends on the interpretation of th=
at pattern. I am still 
looking for ways to achieve this. As you see I trie=
d some, but there 
are more possibilities that need to be explored. General=
ly I believe I 
am on the right way this time. 

Here is one insight I just=
 had right now. The same class of object can 
actually be allowed to grow i=
n varying sizes, depending on the 
*inputs* to the CPPN. Considering the fa=
ct that plants can grow to 
gigantic sizes if boosted with the proper nutri=
tion. So body size can 
be made relative to the inputs of the CPPN somehow.=
 Then we can drop 
body size as something we ask the CPPN for, but provide =
it or make it 
dependant on the environment. A big tree and a small tree of=
 the same 
species is still a tree, so forget about size, only the complexi=
ty and 
the finite nature of the body have to be inside the encoding. 

The=
 method with the egg that I described earlier implements this idea 
in a ve=
ry limited way. But I am sure it is something that is worth 
exploring.

Pe=
ter

ote:

metho=

ughts?  Do you think there still may be a non-growth way of doing

 By the way, I was also wondering if you think that your method can

etically produce any configuration of nodes or if it is limited

l subset of possible density patterns?
